sentences: Sabrina Annlynn Carpenter (born May 11, 1999) is an American singer and actress.
section: N/A

sentences: Carpenter made her acting debut with an appearance in the crime series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit and received recognition for her recurring role as a young Chloe Goodwin in The Goodwin Games.
section: N/A

sentences: She had her breakthrough starring as Maya Hart in the Disney Channel series Girl Meets World (2014–2017).
section: N/A

sentences: Carpenter has starred in the feature films Horns (2013), The Hate U Give (2018), Adventures in Babysitting (2016) and as Sammy Brown in the teen drama Clouds (2020).
section: N/A

sentences: She has starred in the Netflix films, Tall Girl (2019) and Work It (2020).
section: N/A

sentences: As a voice actress, she had a recurring role as Princess Vivian in Sofia the First (2013–2018), and as Melissa Chase on Milo Murphy's Law (2016–2019).
section: N/A

sentences: In 2014, Carpenter was signed to Hollywood Records.
section: N/A

sentences: Her debut single, Can't Blame a Girl for Trying and EP of the same name, were released in the same year.
section: N/A

sentences: She released her debut album, Eyes Wide Open, in 2015 and has gone on to release three studio albums: Evolution (2016), Singular: Act I (2018), and Singular: Act II (2019).
section: N/A

sentences: After departing from Hollywood Records, Carpenter was signed by Island Records in 2021.

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Carpenter was born on May 11, 1999, in Lehigh Valley, Pennsylvania, to David and Elizabeth Carpenter, and was raised alongside her three older sisters; Sarah, Shannon, and half-sister Cayla.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She is a niece of actress Nancy Cartwright.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Carpenter was homeschooled and began posting videos on YouTube of her singing at the age of 10.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Her father built a purple recording studio for her to fuel her passion for music.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She placed third in a singing contest run by Miley Cyrus titled The Next Miley Cyrus Project.
section: == Early life ==

== Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: Carpenter booked her first acting role in 2011, a guest role on the NBC drama series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: She played a young rape victim interviewed by Detective Elliot Stabler (Christopher Meloni).
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: Around the same time, she performed live on the Chinese television station Hunan Broadcasting System for the Gold Mango Audience festival.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: She performed Etta James' "Something's Got a Hold on Me", in the style of Christina Aguilera from the movie Burlesque.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: Less than two years later, Carpenter booked a series recurring role on Fox's The Goodwin Games as Young Chloe, a series regular role on Disney Channel pilot Gulliver Quinn, and the ABC pilot The Unprofessional.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: She portrayed young Merrin in the 2013 film Horns.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: Carpenter performed "Smile" for the album Disney Fairies: Faith, Trust, and Pixie Dust"; the song charted on Radio Disney.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: Her song "All You Need" is featured on the Sofia the First soundtrack.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: In January 2013, Carpenter was cast as Maya Hart in the Disney Channel series Girl Meets World, opposite Rowan Blanchard.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: The series is a sequel to the 1993–2000 ABC series Boy Meets World.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===

sentences: Carpenter also signed a five-record deal as a musical artist with Hollywood Records.
section: == Career == | === 2011–2013: Career beginnings and Girl Meets World ===
== Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: On March 14, 2014, Carpenter's debut single, "Can't Blame a Girl for Trying", premiered on Radio Disney and was released on iTunes later in the day.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: The song is the title track on her debut EP which was released on April 8 and was generally well received.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: Carpenter is featured on the Girl Meets World theme song, "Take On The World", which also features her co-star Blanchard.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: Carpenter performed the song "Stand Out" in the Disney Channel Original Movie How to Build a Better Boy, which premiered August 15, 2014, on Disney Channel.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: On July 20, 2014, Carpenter contributed lead vocals to Disney Channel Circle of Stars' cover version of "Do You Want to Build a Snowman?"In January 2015, it was announced that Carpenter, along with Sofia Carson, would star in a Disney Channel Original Movie, then titled Further Adventures in Babysitting, based on the 1987 movie Adventures in Babysitting.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: On February 22, Carpenter announced the title of her debut album, Eyes Wide Open.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: It was preceded by the debut single "We'll Be the Stars", which was released on January 13, 2015.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: The album was originally to be released April 21, 2015, but the release date was moved and the album was released on April 14, 2015.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: In 2015 she won a Radio Disney Music Award in the category "Best Crush Song" for her song "Can't Blame a Girl For Trying".
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: In December 2015 Carpenter played Wendy in the Pasadena Playhouse's production of Peter Pan and Tinker Bell: A Pirate's Christmas.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: "Smoke and Fire", initially planned as the lead for her second album, Evolution, was released in February 2016, but it was later dropped from the album.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: "On Purpose" became the lead single for that album, which was released on October 14.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: The second single, "Thumbs", found commercial success peaking at number one on Billboard's Bubbling Under Hot 100 singles chart.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: On April 17, 2017, she performed the song on The Late Late Show with James Corden.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: In 2017, Carpenter recorded the theme song for the series Andi Mack, titled "Tomorrow Starts Today".
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: She collaborated with The Vamps and Mike Perry for the single "Hands", which was released on May 19, 2017.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: In 2017, she toured Europe with The Vamps, and she did a summer tour with New Hope Club.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: On October 13, 2017, Lost Kings released a single called "First Love" featuring Sabrina Carpenter.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: Her single "Why", produced by Jonas Jeberg, was released on July 7, 2017.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: In 2017, Carpenter sang "You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch" on Lindsey Stirling's holiday album Warmer in the Winter.
section: == Career == | === 2014–2017: Eyes Wide Open, EVOLution and other work ===

sentences: In December 2017, Carpenter released a cover of "Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas".

sentences: She released the single, titled "Almost Love", on June 6, 2018.
section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: A few days before the release of the single, Carpenter released a trailer for her third album, announcing that the album was titled Singular and had a planned release date of late 2018.
section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: When performing "Almost Love" on The Late Late Show with James Corden in October 2018, Carpenter ended the performance by spray painting "11/9" on the wall, indicating the release date to be November 9, 2018.
section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: On October 22, 2018, she formally announced the album's release date and that it would be released in two "acts", with Act I on November 9, and Act II "coming soon".
section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: She performed the album's second single, "Sue Me", on Live with Kelly and Ryan and The Today Show on November 9, 2018, the same day of Act I's release.
section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: On March 2, 2019, Carpenter embarked on the Singular Tour starting in Orlando, Florida, where she performed two new songs from Singular: Act II, "Pushing 20" and "Exhale".

sentences: On March 8, 2019, "Pushing 20" was released as the album's lead single.

sentences: "Exhale" was released on May 3, 2019.

sentences: She released the single "In My Bed" on June 7, 2019.

sentences: On July 5, 2019, Carpenter performed on Good Morning America's Summer Concert Series where she debuted the performances of "On My Way" and "In My Bed".
section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: She also performed "Sue Me", "Why", and the promotional single "Paris" from Act I. In January 2019, Carpenter was cast as Harper in the Netflix film Tall Girl.

section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: Carpenter made her Broadway debut as Cady Heron in Mean Girls on March 10, 2020, and was set to have a limited run that ended on June 7.

sentences: However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, all Broadway theatres closed on March 12 and will not reopen until September 2021, thus cutting her limited run short.

sentences: On January 7, 2021, it was announced that Mean Girls would not reopen.
section: == Career == | === 2018–2020: Singular, broadway debut and acting endeavors ===

sentences: In April 2020, Carpenter appeared in a charity version of "If the World Was Ending" by JP Saxe and Julia Michaels, which supported Doctors Without Borders in the COVID-19 pandemic.

== Career == | === 2021–present: New label ===

sentences: 2021–present: New label ===
section: == Career == | === 2021–present: New label ===

sentences: In January 2021, Carpenter released the single "Skin" on January 22, 2021, which debuted at number 48 and became Carpenter's first Billboard Hot 100 entry.
section: == Career == | === 2021–present: New label ===

sentences: The song acts as Carpenter's first release with Island Records, following her departure from Hollywood Records.
section: == Career == | === 2021–present: New label ===

sentences: She released a follow-up song titled "Skinny Dipping", co-written with Julia Michaels and JP Saxe.
section: == Career == | === 2021–present: New label ===

sentences: In February 2022, Carpenter released "Fast Times".
section: == Career == | === 2021–present: New label ===
== Artistry ==

sentences: Artistry ==
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: Sabrina Carpenter has been described as a "teen pop" singer who has explored other genres on different albums including pop, folk pop, acoustic, and country on Eyes Wide Open.
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: Evolution included genres such as electropop and house music.
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: Singular: Act I and Singular: Act II dived into "more mature" genres and lyrical content including dance-pop, trap, hip-hop, and R&B.
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: In an interview with Disney Insider, Carpenter cited Christina Aguilera, Adele, and Rihanna as musical influences.
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: She also cited Whitney Houston and Etta James as early musical influences in an interview with Refinery29.
section: == Artistry ==

sentences: She has taken inspiration from the songwriting of Taylor Swift and Lorde.
section: == Artistry ==
